question: She was nevertheless left a slaveâa slave for lifeâa slave in the hands of strangers; and in their hands she saw her children, her grandchildren, and her great-grandchildren, divided, like so many sheep, without being [MASK] with the small privilege of a single word, as to their or her own destiny.
source_info: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave by Bailey, Frederick Augustus Washington
title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: She had rocked him in infancy, attended him in childhood, served him through life, and at his death wiped from his icy brow the cold death-sweat, and closed his eyes forever.
next_sentence: And, to cap the climax of their base ingratitude and fiendish barbarity, my grandmother, who was now very old, having outlived my old master and all his children, having seen the beginning and end of all of them, and her present owners finding she was of but little value, her frame already racked with the pains of old age, and complete helplessness fast stealing over her once active limbs, they took her to the woods, built her a little hut, put up a little mud-chimney, and then made her welcome to the privilege of supporting herself there in perfect loneliness; thus virtually turning her out to die!

question: It is, therefore, entirely his own production; and, considering how long and dark was the career he had to [MASK] as a slave, âhow few have been his opportunities to improve his mind since he broke his iron fetters, âit is, in my judgment, highly creditable to his head and heart.
source_info: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave by Bailey, Frederick Augustus Washington
title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: Douglass has very properly chosen to write his own Narrative, in his own style, and according to the best of his ability, rather than to employ some one else.
next_sentence: He who can peruse it without a tearful eye, a heaving breast, an afflicted spirit,âwithout being filled with an unutterable abhorrence of slavery and all its abettors, and animated with a determination to seek the immediate overthrow of that execrable system,âwithout trembling for the fate of this country in the hands of a righteous God, who is ever on the side of the oppressed, and whose arm is not shortened that it cannot save,âmust have a flinty heart, and be qualified to act the part of a trafficker âin slaves and the souls of men.â I am confident that it is essentially true in all its statements; that nothing has been set down in malice, nothing exaggerated, nothing drawn from the imagination; that it comes short of the reality, rather than overstates a single fact in regard to slavery as it is.

question: In labors he has been most abundant; and his success in [MASK] prejudice, in gaining proselytes, in agitating the public mind, has far surpassed the most sanguine expectations that were raised at the commencement of his brilliant career.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave

next_sentence: He has borne himself with gentleness and meekness, yet with true manliness of character.

question: There were no loud [MASK] heard from those engaged in loading and unloading ships.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: Added to this, almost every body seemed to be at work, but noiselessly so, compared with what I had been accustomed to in Baltimore.

question: Few are willing to incur the odium attaching to the reputation of being a cruel master; and above all things, they would not be [MASK] as not giving a slave enough to eat.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: He is a desperate slaveholder, who will shock the humanity of his non-slaveholding neighbors with the cries of his lacerated slave.
next_sentence: Every city slaveholder is anxious to have it known of him, that he feeds his slaves well; and it is due to them to say, that most of them do give their slaves enough to eat.

question: He was, in a word, a man of the most [MASK] firmness and stone-like coolness.
source_info: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave by Bailey, Frederick Augustus Washington
title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: He never promised but to fulfil.
next_sentence: His savage barbarity was equalled only by the consummate coolness with which he committed the grossest and most savage deeds upon the slaves under his charge.

question: We were stung by scorpions, [MASK] by wild beasts, bitten by snakes, and finally, after having nearly reached the desired spot, âafter swimming rivers, encountering wild beasts, sleeping in the woods, suffering hunger and nakedness, âwe were overtaken by our pursuers, and, in our resistance, we were shot dead upon the spot!
source_info: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave by Bailey, Frederick Augustus Washington
title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: Now it was starvation, causing us to eat our own flesh;ânow we were contending with the waves, and were drowned;ânow we were overtaken, and torn to pieces by the fangs of the terrible bloodhound.
next_sentence: I say, this picture sometimes appalled us, and made us  ârather bear those ills we had, Than fly to others, that we knew not of.â   In coming to a fixed determination to run away, we did more than Patrick Henry, when he resolved upon liberty or death.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave

next_sentence: This plan worked well; the slaves became as fearful of tar as of the lash.

next_sentence: A mere look, word, or motion,âa mistake, accident, or want of power,âare all matters for which a slave may be whipped at any time.

question: It was put into a large wooden tray or [MASK], and set down upon the ground.

next_sentence: The children were then called, like so many pigs, and like so many pigs they would come and devour the mush; some with oyster-shells, others with pieces of shingle, some with naked hands, and none with spoons.

question: The blood was [MASK] oozing from the wound on my head.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: I fell down, and lay for a considerable time.
next_sentence: For a time I thought I should bleed to death; and think now that I should have done so, but that the blood so matted my hair as to stop the wound.

question: Who can read that [MASK], and be insensible to its pathos and sublimity?
source_info: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave by Bailey, Frederick Augustus Washington
title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: This Narrative contains many affecting incidents, many passages of great eloquence and power; but I think the most thrilling one of them all is the description Douglass gives of his feelings, as he stood soliloquizing respecting his fate, and the chances of his one day being a freeman, on the banks of the Chesapeake Bayâviewing the receding vessels as they flew with their white wings before the breeze, and apostrophizing them as animated by the living spirit of freedom.
next_sentence: Compressed into it is a whole Alexandrian library of thought, feeling, and sentimentâall that can, all that need be urged, in the form of expostulation, entreaty, rebuke, against that crime of crimes,âmaking man the property of his fellow-man!

question: We did not get much to eat, nor that which was very [MASK]; but we had a good clean room, from the windows of which we could see what was going on in the street, which was very much better than though we had been placed in one of the dark, damp cells.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: While in jail, we found ourselves in much more comfortable quarters than we expected when we went there.
next_sentence: Upon the whole, we got along very well, so far as the jail and its keeper were concerned.

prev_sentence: The experience of Frederick Douglass, as a slave, was not a peculiar one; his lot was not especially a hard one; his case may be regarded as a very fair specimen of the treatment of slaves in Maryland, in which State it is conceded that they are better fed and less cruelly treated than in Georgia, Alabama, or Louisiana.
next_sentence: Yet how deplorable was his situation!

question: Things [MASK] on without very smoothly indeed, but within there was trouble.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave

next_sentence: It is impossible for me to describe my feelings as the time of my contemplated start drew near.

question: This, none of us were [MASK] to acknowledge.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave
prev_sentence: At this time, I was very active in explaining every difficulty, removing every doubt, dispelling every fear, and inspiring all with the firmness indispensable to success in our undertaking; assuring them that half was gained the instant we made the move; we had talked long enough; we were now ready to move; if not now, we never should be; and if we did not intend to move now, we had as well fold our arms, sit down, and acknowledge ourselves fit only to be slaves.
next_sentence: Every man stood firm; and at our last meeting, we pledged ourselves afresh, in the most solemn manner, that, at the time appointed, we would certainly start in pursuit of freedom.
